Award.AwardTitle: Heterocycle Synthesis Through Reversible Allylic Alcohol Transposition and Stereoselective Capture
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Paul Floreancig at the University of Pittsburgh develops new chemical reactions in which reversibility is coupled with a secondary step to increase molecular complexity and generate stereocenters. The approach is to expose allylic alcohols that contain an electrophilic group to rhenium oxide or other catalysts that effect non-stereoselective transpositions. The transposition will proceed until an intramolecular reaction occurs in which stereochemical control will be dictated by thermodynamic, kinetic, or catalyst control. A number of elements will be incorporated into the reaction substrates to demonstrate that reaction outcomes can be manipulated rationally through applications of basic principles and molecular modeling. The target structures have been selected due to their relevance to the synthesis of natural products.

The coupling of stereocontrol with ring formation that will be developed in this work can significantly reduce the effort that is required for complex molecule synthesis. This will benefit the fields of medicinal chemistry and materials science. The mild conditions that are used for these reactions will make the processes attractive for chemical manufacturing applications. The broader impacts of this work lie in the use of these processes as a tool for highlighting the manner in which thermodynamics and kinetics can be manipulated for complex reaction design, and in the use of travel funds to present seminars at colleges that have a high enrollment of underrepresented minority students. In addition, this project provides research training to graduate students and contributes to workforce development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research that was conducted during tis award period was directed toward devising new chemical reactions that provide significant increases in molecular complexity. Complex structures generally show greater selectivity in promoting biological responses, but they are difficult to access. These studies provided several examples of increasing molecular complexity through simple, environmentally benign processes.

One study was dedicated to preparing cyclic molecules from non-cyclic precursors through a dehydrative cyclization (a reaction in which water is the only by-product). This method was applied to the synthesis of the spliceosome inhibitor heroxidiene and its analogs. Spliceosome inhibition is an exciting approach in cancer therapy and access to inhibitors will be useful for these studies. A collaboration to study the anti-cancer potential for these molecules has been established.

A second study was directed to using epoxides, which are easily accessible but highly reactive molecules, in cascade cyclizations that provide multiple rings in a single transformation. Several off these reactions are perfectly atom economical, meaning that no waste is generated in converting the starting material to the product. The products that are formed through this protocol are polyethers that can have a number of applications including serving as potential drugs or biological probes.

The final project was directed toward developing a bimolecular variant of the process. All previous work was directed toward studying unimolecular reactions, which leads to products that are only the same size or smaller than the starting materials. Bimolecular reactions provide opportunities to make products that are larger than the starting materials, which is essential in the construction of complex targets. This project was successful and also led to the development of a dual catalyst approach to designing new reactions. Dual catalyst approaches are useful because each catalyst can conduct a transformation that is independent of the transformation that the other catalyst promotes, however they are rare because finding catalysts that do not interfere with each others' reactivity is difficult. This work showed that rhenium oxide, which is useful for promoting allylic alcohol transposition, can be merged with hydrogen bonding catalysts, which promote ionization and bimolecular coupling.

These projects have provided training to three graduate students (one female). The results have been disseminated through the publication of papers and book chapters, and through seminars at colleges, universities, and conferences. This work is particularly well-suited for seminars at undergraduate institutions, and I have used part of my travel budget to visit HBCUs such as Xavier University of New Orleans. These visits allow me to discuss science careers with promising students from underrepresented minority groups.
